entry.note: short version of global assert range used in reports

message.entry:
NO - Global Assert will not be applied.
YES - After each assignment, an assert check is performed, controlling the specified range.
The assert check is also performed during global initialization.

MAIN GENERATOR - Mode depends on the main generator options.
NONE - Not initialized.
SINGLE - The pointed object or first element (array) is written.
MULTI - The pointed object is completely written. For example, all elements of an array are written.
SINGLE_CERTAIN_WRITE - The pointed object or first element (array) is definitely written.
MULTI_CERTAIN_WRITE - The pointed object is definitely and completely written. For example all elements of an array are definitely written.

When SINGLE_CERTAIN_WRITE (MULTI_CERTAIN_WRITE) is available, SINGLE (MULTI) denote potential writing
of the pointed object. Use SINGLE_CERTAIN_WRITE (MULTI_CERTAIN_WRITE) for definite writing.

MAIN GENERATOR - Mode will depend on the main generator options.
IGNORE - The variable is not assigned to the specified range.
INIT - The variable is assigned the specified range only at initialization. The range is kept until the first write operation.
PERMANENT - The variable is permanently assigned the specified range.

If the variable is assigned a value outside the specified range during the program execution, no warning is provided.

To get a warning when the variable is assigned a value outside the specified range, use the Global Assert mode.
NOTE: You cannot use Global Assert with PERMANENT.

Maybe NULL - Pointer may be initialized to NULL.
Not NULL - Pointer will never be initialized to NULL.
NULL - Pointer will always be initialized to NULL.

MAIN GENERATOR - Mode will depend on the main generator options.
NO - Will not be called by the main generator.
YES - Will be called by the main generator.
Functionality available with the Polyspace Code Prover product.

No constraint file specified. To specify this file:
  • Click Generate, which creates a new constraint file.
  • Click the folder icon and navigate to an existing constraint file.

No external constraint specified. To specify constraints, click the folder icon and navigate to an existing constraint file.
If you have run a Polyspace analysis at least once before, you can find a constraints template file in the existing Polyspace results folder:
  • Navigate to an existing results folder and locate the 'drs-template.xml' file.
  • Copy this file to your project folder and rename it.
  • Click the folder icon above and navigate to the renamed constraints file.

Warning
Save the specified constraints to a new file before editing.
{0}\nDo you want to save it somewhere else?

Note
To account for constraint specifications changes when
regenerating your results, update the project configuration option
(Constraint setup) to point to the chosen file.
Update constraints to reflect source code changes.
The value must be an integer > 0 or 'max'
For {0} type, a value must be in the following range : {1}
The value must be either a float, integer, hexadecimal or the keywords 'min' or 'max'. Use '..' for a range.\nFor example, '1..9' for an integer or '2.0..4.0' for a float.
A floating point value has been entered for an integer type.
XML format not accepted. Select another file.
Polyspace Test does not support external range constraints.\nThis option applies only to Polyspace static analysis products.
